Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Astronomy and Astrophysics at Cornell University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site in Astronomy and Astrophysics at Cornell University. The program aims to provide undergraduate students from across the country with the opportunity to engage actively in research covering a broad swath of the science frontier from the Solar System to the extreme environments surrounding black holes to the distant reaches and earliest moments of the universe. Students will work with individual faculty on a focused research project. In addition, they will also participate in a series of lectures and workshops designed particularly to expose them to a range of research topics, techniques and forefront facilities as well as the processes by which major facilities and missions are designed, constructed and operated. While primary mentoring responsibility will lie with the faculty, interactions within research groups will provide contact with more junior professionals such as graduate students and postdoctoral students as well as engineers and technical staff.

Students will have access to local resources and facilities and will learn how to access and use public databases and software tools. Organized activities on our residential rural campus, sometimes in coordination with other undergraduate research programs within our university, will offer the opportunity to expose the students to broader science areas and to stimulate understanding of the nature, methodology and ethics of scientific research on a scale larger than our own program. The program will encourage mentors to take students on observing trips, to assist with development of publications and other presentations, and to send them to professional meetings. Students will also participate in several activities designed to address issues related to graduate school and science as a career. Students will be selected on merit, but the program will aim to recruit diverse student cohorts including students from underrepresented groups and from colleges and universities with limited research infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Astronomy and Astrophysics at Cornell University is a ten week residential summer research undergraduate program for students that have shown potential for scientific research through their institutions and for whom immersion in a program at a major research university would provide great benefit. It seeks to widen the pipeline of future scientists and STEM professionals and increase access to careers in astrophysics, planetary science and related fields by exposing students to broad areas of current research, fostering appreciation of the research enterprise and their possible place within it and helping them identify and develop key career skills.

Our program combines Cornell’s strengths in broad areas of the astronomy research frontier with our experience and commitment to involve undergraduates in all aspects of our research. We provide students independent research opportunities under the mentorship of our faculty and their teams, make the program accessible to students across the country from groups underrepresented in STEM, and recruit the students best suited to take advantage of it. Our program emphasizes

  • the intimate and intensive interactions which take place within small research groups
  • the intellectual advantages of a broad and diverse research environment and
  • the cohort building possible in a summer experience at a major research university in a rural setting.

The program includes activities designed to

  • help students explore areas of astrophysics and planetary science different from what they were working on via a lecture series covering a wide swath of topics and in-depth workshops providing a synthesis of research frontiers;
  • help them develop critical professional skills (e.g., coding, oral and poster presentations) via workshops, team meetings and practice;
  • educate them in the nature, methodology and ethics of scientific research facilities; (4) to help them understand their professional options;
  • help them understand the role of teamwork in STEM.

Our program offers students from institutions with fewer research resources in our field than Cornell access to such resources and the opportunity to acquire knowledge and experience not only from our research teams but also by exposing them to a diverse cohort of other undergraduates. Of the 45 students the NSF has funded, less than half (16) came from universities with the highest research activity in Astronomy; 11 came from institutions offering predominantly master’s degrees; 9 came from predominantly bachelor’s degree granting colleges ; 7 came from universities with high or moderate research activity in Astronomy and two from colleges offering predominantly associates degrees. Nineteen (47%) were female and 26 (53%) male. Four (9%) were Latinos, one (2%) African American, and one (2%) American Indian. One student was a single parent. More than half (25) are currently in graduate school in a STEM field, most of them astronomy or planetary science. Eight are still in college, three work in industry, two are science educators, two left STEM and one is deceased. In addition to the NSF-funded students, the program has incorporated an additional 74 undergraduates funded by research grants or private endowments whose participation enriched the experience of the NSF/REU students and multiplied the effects of the grant we received. The program has also contributed to the professional development of eleven graduate students, 13 postdocs and 7 senior research associates who have been principal participants in the students’ research or the program.

One of the key insights and experiences we strive to provide our students is that science is the product of collaboration—that novel ideas stem not from lone geniuses but from groups of individuals that simultaneously support and challenge each other’s learning. Cohort formation in our program takes place at all times and in different settings, formal and informal, including very importantly in the co-ops where students are housed.

In collaboration with 76 co-authors at Cornell and other institutions part of their research teams, 27 students presented posters at a professional conference (American Astronomical Society, American Geological Union, or Division of Planetary Sciences). One student was a main author and two co-authors in three papers published in the Journal for Geophysical Research- Planets, Icarus, and, the third, a groundbreaking article on fast radio bursts published in Nature. In addition, our students have produced or contributed to astronomical instrumentation, databases, software, a webpage and a press conference. Four students have received NSF Graduate Research Fellowships, 6 have received NSF GRF Honorable Mentions; 4 have received Chambliss Awards from the American Astronomical Society,  and one has received a McNair Scholarship.

Cornell’s REU program gives a diverse group of students, including students from institutions with smaller colleges and universities without major astronomy research programs who have not previously had off-campus research experiences and/or have non-traditional academic backgrounds, access to a research experience that provides them with critical tools to develop the professional skills and identity that are key to future success in their career paths.
